title: Narcolepsy
scope: ** Diagnosis and management of narcolepsy type 1 (with cataplexy/orexin deficiency) and type 2 (without cataplexy) in adults. Covers diagnostic workup including PSG/MSLT, CSF orexin, pharmacologic treatment of excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy, and long-term management. Excludes idiopathic hypersomnia as separate entity, Kleine-Levin syndrome, and secondary narcolepsy due to structural brain lesions.

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Iron deficiency contributes to EDS and RLS comorbidity
Exclude substance use causing sleepiness; required pre-MSLT

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: CSF hypocretin-1 / orexin-A (sent to Stanford reference lab)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Definitive diagnosis of NT1 if ≤110 pg/mL; useful when MSLT equivocal or impractical
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: ≤110 pg/mL diagnostic of NT1; >200 pg/mL normal

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Present in >90% of NT1; supportive but not diagnostic (also in 25% general population)
Diabetes screening; metabolic contributors to fatigue

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Pediatric/young adult onset following streptococcal infection
Research biomarker for autoimmune etiology of NT1

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Definitive biomarker for NT1; ≤110 pg/mL diagnostic

Essential/First-line.timing: Night before MSLT; required for MSLT interpretation
Essential/First-line.target: Exclude OSA, PLMD; document SOREMP within 15 min

Essential/First-line.timing: Day following PSG; at least 2 weeks off REM-suppressant medications
Essential/First-line.target: Mean sleep latency ≤8 min with ≥2 SOREMPs
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Must have preceding PSG; stop REM-suppressants 2 weeks prior

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If secondary narcolepsy suspected (structural hypothalamic lesion)
Extended.target: Rule out hypothalamic mass, demyelination, sarcoidosis
≥7 hours nightly sleep for 2 weeks before MSLT

Rare/Specialized.timing: If initial MSLT equivocal or performed while on REM-suppressants

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: EDS management; adjunct to all pharmacotherapy

dosing.instructions: 15-20 minute naps 1-2 times daily; schedule at predictable times (mid-morning, early afternoon)

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Consolidate nocturnal sleep; reduce daytime sleepiness

dosing.instructions: Regular sleep-wake schedule; 7-9 hours nightly; cool dark room; limit screen time before bed
Avoid alcohol, sedating antihistamines, benzodiazepines; limit caffeine to morning only

Non-Pharmacologic Treatment (All Patient.indication: Prevent injury from sleepiness or cataplexy

dosing.instructions: Driving restrictions until EDS controlled; avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery
Start 100 mg each morning; increase to 200 mg daily after 1 week; may split 200 mg AM + 200 mg early afternoon if needed; max 400 mg/day

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe hepatic impairment; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives
First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.monitoring: Blood pressure; rash (rare Stevens-Johnson); sleep quality; contraceptive efficacy

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.indication: First-line wake-promoting agent for EDS; longer duration than modafinil

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg each morning; may increase to 250 mg daily; longer half-life than modafinil; max 250 mg/day

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe hepatic impairment; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives
First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.monitoring: Blood pressure; rash (rare Stevens-Johnson); sleep quality; contraceptive efficacy

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.indication: EDS in narcolepsy; dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg once daily upon awakening; may increase to 150 mg daily after ≥3 days; max 150 mg/day for narcolepsy

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled hypertension; severe renal impairment (eGFR <15); end-stage renal disease
First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; psychiatric symptoms; weight; renal function

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.indication: EDS and cataplexy in narcolepsy; histamine-3 receptor antagonist/inverse agonist

dosing.instructions: Start 8.9 mg once daily upon awakening; titrate weekly: 8.9 mg to 17.8 mg to 35.6 mg; max 35.6 mg/day

First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP2D6 inhibitors (max 17.8 mg); QT-prolonging drugs
First-Line Treatment - Excessive Daytime.monitoring: QTc interval if risk factors; hepatic function; insomnia; headache

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.indication: First-line for cataplexy; also improves EDS and disrupted nocturnal sleep; REMS program (Xyrem REMS)

dosing.instructions: Start 4.5 g/night divided into 2 equal doses (2.25 g at bedtime + 2.25 g 2.5-4 hours later); titrate by 1.5 g/night every 1-2 weeks; effective range 6-9 g/night; max 9 g/night

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.contraindications: Succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency; concurrent sedative-hypnotics or alcohol; concurrent opioids; untreated sleep-disordered breathing
Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.monitoring: Respiratory depression; CNS depression; sleepwalking; depression/suicidality; sodium intake (high sodium content); abuse potential

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.indication: First-line for cataplexy; 92% less sodium than Xyrem; also improves EDS and disrupted nocturnal sleep; REMS program (Xywav REMS)

dosing.instructions: Start 4.5 g/night divided into 2 equal doses at bedtime and 2.5-4 hours later; titrate by 1.5 g/night every 1-2 weeks; max 9 g/night

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.contraindications: Succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase deficiency; concurrent sedative-hypnotics or alcohol; concurrent opioids
Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.monitoring: Respiratory depression; CNS depression; sleepwalking; depression/suicidality; abuse potential

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.indication: Anticataplectic agent; also treats comorbid depression and anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily; increase by 37.5-75 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 75-225 mg/day; max 225 mg/day

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled hypertension; abrupt discontinuation risk
Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation symptoms if stopped abruptly; suicidality in young adults

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.indication: Anticataplectic agent; also treats comorbid depression

dosing.instructions: Start 10-20 mg daily; increase by 10-20 mg every 2-4 weeks; target 20-60 mg/day; max 80 mg/day

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; concurrent pimozide or thioridazine
Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.monitoring: Serotonin syndrome; QTc at higher doses; activation/insomnia; suicidality in young adults

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.indication: Potent anticataplectic agent; tricyclic antidepressant with strong REM-suppressive properties

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg at bedtime; titrate by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 25-75 mg/day; max 150 mg/day

Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.contraindications: Recent MI; concurrent MAOIs; cardiac conduction disease; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma
Treatment - Cataplexy and REM-Related Sy.monitoring: ECG if dose >75 mg/day or age >40; anticholinergic effects; orthostatic hypotension; weight gain; sexual dysfunction

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.indication: EDS refractory to first-line agents; rapid onset of action

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID (morning and early afternoon); titrate by 5-10 mg/week; max 60 mg/day; avoid evening dosing

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; severe anxiety or agitation; motor tics/Tourette; glaucoma; structural cardiac abnormalities
Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; weight; appetite; growth (pediatric); psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.indication: EDS refractory to modafinil/solriamfetol; potent wake-promoting agent

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg once or twice daily; titrate by 5 mg/week; max 60 mg/day; avoid evening dosing

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; advanced atherosclerosis; symptomatic cardiovascular disease; moderate-severe hypertension; glaucoma; agitated states; history of drug abuse
Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; weight; appetite; psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential (Schedule II)

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.indication: EDS refractory to first-line agents; combined amphetamine formulation

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg once or twice daily; titrate by 5-10 mg/week; max 60 mg/day; avoid evening dosing

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; advanced atherosclerosis; symptomatic cardiovascular disease; moderate-severe hypertension; glaucoma; agitated states; history of drug abuse
Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; weight; appetite; psychiatric symptoms; abuse potential (Schedule II)

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.indication: Anticataplectic agent with stimulant properties; less sedating TCA

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg in the morning; titrate by 5-10 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 60 mg/day

Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.contraindications: Recent MI; concurrent MAOIs; cardiac conduction disease; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma
Second-Line / Refractory Treatment.monitoring: ECG if dose >20 mg/day or age >40; anticholinergic effects; dry mouth; urinary retention

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.indication: Disrupted nocturnal sleep; circadian rhythm support

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg 30 minutes before bedtime; may help consolidate nighttime sleep
Start 25-50 mg at bedtime; max 100 mg; avoid if nocturnal oxybate used

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; may worsen daytime sedation

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.indication: EDS with comorbid ADHD; norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor with mild anticataplectic properties

dosing.instructions: Start 40 mg daily; increase to 80 mg after ≥3 days; max 100 mg/day

Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; narrow-angle glaucoma; pheochromocytoma; severe cardiovascular disease
Adjunctive / Symptomatic Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; hepatic function (rare hepatotoxicity); suicidality in children/adolescents

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine specialist for PSG/MSLT scheduling, diagnosis confirmation, and treatment optimization
Neurology for evaluation of secondary causes if structural brain lesion suspected or atypical presentation
Psychiatry for management of comorbid depression, anxiety, or behavioral issues associated with narcolepsy
Social work for disability evaluation, vocational counseling, and community resource coordination
Occupational therapy for workplace accommodation strategies and energy conservation techniques
Pulmonology if concurrent obstructive sleep apnea identified on PSG requiring CPAP titration

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Narcolepsy is a lifelong neurological condition caused by loss of brain cells that produce hypocretin; it is not laziness or a psychological problem
Do not drive until excessive daytime sleepiness is adequately controlled with treatment (risk of sleep attacks at the wheel)
Report to state DMV as required by local law; obtain fitness-to-drive evaluation through MWT when applicable
Take scheduled 15-20 minute naps during the day to improve alertness (naps are therapeutic, not a sign of inadequate treatment)
Do not abruptly stop antidepressant medications used for cataplexy as this may cause severe rebound cataplexy (status cataplecticus)
Notify all providers about narcolepsy diagnosis before any sedation or anesthesia (heightened sensitivity to sedatives)
Avoid alcohol, which worsens excessive sleepiness and disrupts nocturnal sleep
Wear medical alert identification stating narcolepsy diagnosis, especially if taking sodium oxybate
Narcolepsy Network (narcolepsynetwork.org) and Wake Up Narcolepsy (wakeupnarcolepsy.org) for patient resources and support groups

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain strict sleep-wake schedule with consistent bedtime and wake time to consolidate nocturnal sleep
Regular moderate exercise (30 minutes daily) to improve alertness and overall health; avoid vigorous exercise close to bedtime
Avoid heavy meals during the day as postprandial sleepiness exacerbates EDS
Limit caffeine to morning hours only; excessive caffeine may disrupt nighttime sleep without adequately controlling EDS
Inform employer about narcolepsy for reasonable workplace accommodations (scheduled nap breaks, flexible schedule) under ADA
Avoid shift work and jobs requiring sustained vigilance (air traffic control, long-haul driving) unless EDS is well-controlled
Emotional management strategies to reduce cataplexy triggers; cognitive behavioral techniques for emotional regulation
Weight management as narcolepsy type 1 is associated with obesity and metabolic syndrome

differential.features: Snoring, witnessed apneas, obesity; EDS improves with CPAP; no cataplexy; MSLT may show shortened latency but typically <2 SOREMPs
differential.tests: PSG with respiratory scoring; AHI >5 events/hour

differential.features: Prolonged non-refreshing sleep; sleep inertia/drunkenness; no cataplexy; MSLT mean latency ≤8 min but <2 SOREMPs; long total sleep time (>11 hours)
differential.tests: MSLT (<2 SOREMPs); actigraphy showing prolonged sleep; CSF orexin normal

differential.features: Chronic sleep restriction; resolves with sleep extension; no cataplexy; ESS elevated but normalizes with adequate sleep
differential.tests: Sleep diary/actigraphy showing <7 hours habitual sleep; resolution with sleep extension

differential.features: Depressed mood, anhedonia, psychomotor retardation; fatigue more than true sleepiness; no cataplexy; MSLT usually normal
differential.tests: Psychiatric evaluation; PHQ-9; MSLT typically mean latency >8 min

differential.features: Temporal relationship to medication initiation; resolves with dose reduction or discontinuation; no cataplexy
Fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation; no cataplexy; no SOREMPs
Nocturnal limb movements; EDS from sleep disruption; no cataplexy
differential.tests: PSG with PLMS >15/hour without other narcolepsy features

differential.features: Recurrent episodes of hypersomnia lasting days-weeks with cognitive/behavioral changes; asymptomatic between episodes
Sudden falls with loss of consciousness (vs. preserved consciousness in cataplexy); may have postictal confusion
differential.tests: EEG; video-EEG monitoring; no emotional trigger

differential.features: Atypical triggers; prolonged episodes; variable pattern; no other narcolepsy symptoms
differential.tests: PSG/MSLT normal; CSF orexin normal; psychiatric evaluation

Modafinil efficacy for EDS in narcolepsy

Venlafaxine and clomipramine strong recommendation for cataplexy
Scheduled naps improve alertness in narcolepsy
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Bassetti et al. J Sleep Res 2021](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34173288/)

evidence.recommendation: Rebound cataplexy with abrupt antidepressant discontinuation

monitoring.action: Adjust wake-promoting agent dose or switch therapy
Adjust anticataplectic dose; add or switch therapy

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; more frequently if on stimulants or solriamfetol
monitoring.action: Dose reduction; add antihypertensive; switch medication
Dose reduction; cardiology referral if persistent tachycardia
Dietary counseling; exercise; evaluate medication effects
Psychiatric referral; adjust medications; monitor suicidality
Reduce dose or discontinue; correct electrolytes; cardiology referral

monitoring.item: Hepatic function (if on pitolisant or atomoxetine)

monitoring.action: Switch to Xywav (lower-sodium formulation); dietary counseling
Adjust sodium oxybate dose; evaluate comorbid sleep disorders
Reinforce driving restrictions; consider MWT; adjust treatment
Consider non-stimulant alternatives; refer to addiction medicine

disposition.criteria: Majority of patients; newly suspected or established narcolepsy for diagnostic workup and chronic management
Patients requiring in-lab sleep study; schedule PSG night followed by next-day MSLT; ensure REM-suppressants discontinued ≥2 weeks
Severe rebound cataplexy (status cataplecticus) after abrupt discontinuation of anticataplectics; narcolepsy with concurrent medical condition requiring inpatient management
Not typically applicable; consider if respiratory depression from sodium oxybate or overdose
All patients with suspected narcolepsy for diagnostic confirmation and treatment initiation
Atypical presentation; suspected secondary narcolepsy; treatment-refractory cases
Every 2-4 weeks during initial titration; every 3-6 months once stable
